Fig 10 Single Ni atom embedded Janus WSSe monolayer as a cost-effective electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reaction Jia-Xing Guo Investigation Conceptualization Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft ⁎ Shao-Yi Wu Software Project administration Writing – review & editing ⁎ Gao-Jun Zhang Validation Writing – review & editing Qi-Hang Qiu Visualization Writing – review & editing Tian-Hao Guo Visualization Writing – review & editing Department of Applied Physics, School of Physics, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu 611731, China Department of Applied Physics School of Physics University of Electronic Science and Technology of China Chengdu 611731 China Department of Applied Physics, School of Physics, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu 611731, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Designing cost-effective oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalysts is of great significance for achieving the renewable energy conversion of complete water splitting. Herein, in the light of the first-principles methods, a series of new OER electrocatalysts (Fe-, Co- and Ni-WSSe) are designed with single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded in Janus WSSe monolayer (ML) with S or Se vacancy. It indicates that the single Fe, Co and Ni atoms can stably embed Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy and prominently modify the structural, electronic and magnetic properties of the systems. From the calculated Gibbs free energies, Ni-WSSe presents the prominent OER catalytic activity among the pristine Janus WSSe ML and Fe-, Co- and Ni-WSSe systems due to its minimum overpotential of 0.53 V. The high OER catalytic activity of Ni-WSSe stems mainly from the synergistic effect of the Ni atom and the Janus WSSe ML. Present findings suggest that embedding appropriate single transition-metal (TM) atoms is an effective strategy to boost the catalytic activity of Janus WSSe ML for OER, which would facilitate the development of the cost-effective OER electrocatalysts for clean energy conversion. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords First-principles Ni-WSSe Cost-effective electrocatalysts Oxygen evolution reaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With the promotion of industrialization, the consumption and demand for fossil energy has increased sharply and caused serious problems including energy shortage and atmospheric contamination. Fortunately, the emergence of renewable and sustainable novel energy technologies such as water splitting, fuel cells and metal-air batteries holds considerable promise for alleviating these negative impacts [1–3]. Among the above novel energy technologies, electrocatalytic water splitting has become an increasingly popular energy conversion technology due to clean products of hydrogen and oxygen without carbon related residual products [4,5]. It is universally acknowledged that the water splitting process consists of two-part chemical reaction, i.e., a hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) to generate hydrogen and an oxygen evolution reaction (OER) to produce oxygen. Compared to the HER with a two-electron transfer process, the OER exhibits lower reaction efficiency with a four-electron transfer process and requires a relatively higher overpotential to promote the process [6–9]. Thus, the whole reaction efficiency of electrocatalytic water splitting largely depends on the OER process. So, it is quite vital to explore suitable catalysts with high stability and efficiency to promote the sluggish kinetics process of OER. Currently, the most active OER catalysts are generally recognized as RuO2 and IrO2 [10,11]. However, both catalysts are composed of noble metals, with obvious disadvantages of low reserves and high prices. Therefore, further development of alternative OER catalysts with relatively high abundance, low cost, high stability and efficiency is extremely urgent. Noteworthily, the rational design of economical Fe-, Co- and Ni-based electrocatalysts could ensure excellent catalytic performances for OER [12–15]. Particularly, MoS2 nanosheets functionalized by heteroatom (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni) doping can effectively boost the OER process [16–18]. Since the three active transition-metal (TM) elements (Fe, Co, Ni) in the same VIIIB group of the periodic table may have similar chemical properties, which would also exhibit prominent OER catalytic potentialities. Thus, the above three inexpensive and earth-abundant TMs (Fe, Co and Ni) are selected in the current study. Unlike numerous catalysts, single-atom catalysts (SACs) refer to single active atoms dispersed on a given substrate with the advantages of uniform active sites, excellent catalytic activity, high selectivity and maximum atom utilization [19–21]. SACs have been increasingly favored in a series of electrochemical reactions such as HER, OER, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [22–26]. Naturally, the above three TMs (Fe, Co and Ni) SACs attracted our great interest. As is well known, suitable substrates are crucial to ensure the high stability and outstanding catalytic activity of SACs. Two-dimensional (2D) materials have distinct advantages of numerous sites, abundant vacancies and tremendous specific surface areas and can be considered as the suitable substrate materials to effectively support SACs. In this regard, graphene [27,28], graphdiyne [29,30], transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) [31–34], MXenes [35,36], h-BN [37,38] and g-C3N4 [39,40] have been widely studied as the substrates for SACs, which were found to exhibit high stability and prominent catalytic performance. Recently emerging 2D materials with Janus structure such as Janus MoSSe monolayer (ML) has been characterized by the distinctive asymmetry of lower S and upper Se atomic layers, which has attracted extensive attention of researchers [41–47]. It is also worth noting that the unique asymmetric feature of Janus MoSSe ML causes a difference in electronegativity and creates a built-in electric field of up to 0.78 eV across the out-of-plane direction [48,49]. Such an intrinsic electric field could inhibit the carrier recombination and accelerate the carrier migration in the Janus structure, thereby facilitating the catalytic activity of the supported SACs [50]. For example, Janus MoSSe ML modified by single Ni, Pd and Pt atoms exhibits excellent catalytic activity for OER [51,52]. More recently, Lin et al. successfully synthesized another similar Janus-structured 2D material, namely Janus WSSe ML [53]. Subsequently, a series of in-depth studies of the Janus WSSe ML have revealed its promising applications in gas sensors, photocatalysts and thermoelectric devices. Specifically, Chaurasiya and Dixit [54] reported that defective Janus WSSe ML exhibits ultrahigh sensitivity and fast recovery for the adsorption of NH3 and NO2. Ju et al. [55] found that the Janus WSSe ML can act as an excellent photocatalyst for overall water splitting. Chaurasiya et al. [56] demonstrated that the thermoelectric properties of Janus WSSe ML can be enhanced with strain mediated valley degeneracy and serve as a potential thermoelectric device. To our knowledge, there are only a few related studies on Janus WSSe ML as the substrate for supporting SACs, especially those for their OER catalytic properties are still blank. In view that Janus WSSe ML has similar configuration to Janus MoSSe ML, it is expected that the Janus WSSe ML may also have prominent OER catalytic activities. Thus, the exploration of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms modified Janus WSSe ML with high OER catalytic performance is of specific significance. Usually, the electrocatalytic reactions undergo on the surface or interface. The single Fe, Co and Ni atoms are chosen to be embedded on the surface of Janus WSSe ML (i.e., occupying the S or Se site by strongly bonding with the substrate) to fully expose the active sites. The feasibility of the synthesis for the proposed catalysts could be assessed as follows. The formation energy of single S or Se vacancy in Janus WSSe ML is 2.72 or 2.85 eV [54], respectively. These values are smaller than those of the C vacancy in graphene (≈7.80 eV [57]) and B/N vacancy in BN (≈9.99 / 8.33 eV [58]), suggesting that it is easier to form the S or Se vacancy in Janus WSSe ML by electron irradiation [59] or low-energy argon sputtering [60]. Subsequently, single TM atom can be handily embedded in the vacancy of Janus WSSe ML. Therefore, the strategy of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S or Se vacancy is adopted in this research. In this work, we propose a series of new TM-WSSe (TM = Fe, Co and Ni) SACs for OER by utilizing first-principles calculations. Firstly, the structural, electronic and magnetic properties as well as stability of single TM (Fe, Co and Ni) atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S or Se vacancy are comprehensively studied. Then, the specific four-electron transfer processes of OER on pristine and TM-embedded Janus WSSe ML are uniformly analyzed, and single Ni atom embedded Janus WSSe ML (on S/Se vacancy site) is found to exhibit superior OER catalytic performance. Furthermore, the OER catalytic activity of single Ni atom embedded Janus WSSe ML (on S/Se vacancy site) is further evaluated with solvation effect. Finally, the mechanism of Ni-WSSe as a cost-effective OER electrocatalyst is systematically elucidated and summarized. 2 Methods and models The whole spin-polarized calculations are implemented by using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) [61,62] based on the density functional theory (DFT). The interactions between valence electrons and core-ion are dealt with by the projector augmented-wave (PAW) method [63], and the exchange-correlation interactions are treated by the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional of generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [64]. The SACs are modeled by embedding single Fe, Co and Ni atoms into a 4 × 4 supercell of Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. The vacuum thickness of 20 Å is set in the Z-axis direction to prevent the interlayer interferences. Considering the strong correlation influences of TM (Fe, Co and Ni) 3d electrons, an effective Ueff (U - J = 3 eV) of GGA + U algorithm is applied to deal with the strong on-site Coulomb interactions on the basis of previous relevant researches [65,66]. The dipole correction is also taken into consideration in view of the asymmetry of upper Se and lower S atomic layers in Janus WSSe ML. A kinetic energy cutoff of 500 eV is adopted for electron wave functions, and the convergence precisions of 0.01 eV/Å and 10–5 eV are used for residual force and energy of each atom, respectively. The 2D Brillouin zone is sampled by employing Gamma-centered Monkhorst-Pack scheme of 5 × 5 × 1 k-point mesh for structure relaxations, and 11 × 11 × 1 k-point mesh for the computations of electronic properties. In view of the weak effects of van der Waals (vdW) interaction, a DFT-D3 scheme [67] is applied to describe the vdW corrections between oxygenated species (*OH, *O, *OOH, O2) and TM-WSSe catalysts. The climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method [68] is utilized to evaluate the energy barriers of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms diffusing from the embedded S/Se vacancy site to the neighboring optimal W-top site and the next nearest S/Se vacancy site. Six images are set along the diffusion paths between the initial and final states (IS and FS), and a 5 eV/Å spring force is applied to treat the neighboring images. From the frequency calculations, the IS and FS or transition state (TS) are verified with zero or one imaginary frequency. For the OER, the Gibbs free energy change ( Δ G ) of every elementary step can be described in the light of the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model [69,70] as below: (1) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E Z P E − T Δ S + Δ G U + Δ G p H In the equation, Δ E , Δ E Z P E and Δ S correspond to the total energy, zero-point energy (ZPE) and entropy differences between products and reactants, which are obtained from the DFT calculations, vibrational frequency analysis and NIST thermodynamics database, respectively. Δ G U is acquired from -neU, where U and n refer to the electrode potential and the number of transferred electrons, respectively. Δ G p H = k B T ln 10 p H is employed to describe the electrolyte environment, where k B , T and pH stand for Boltzmann constant, absolute temperature of 298.15 K at room temperature and pH value of zero in acidic medium for current work. Since the energy of O2 molecule usually cannot be directly and accurately calculated by the DFT, it could be obtained from the equation G O 2 = 2 G H 2 O − 2 G H 2 + 4.92 (eV) [71]. To effectively and quantitatively measure OER catalytic activity, the overpotential (ηOER) is introduced as: (2) η O E R = max Δ G / e − 1.23 V where the value 1.23 V denotes the equilibrium potential of OER. Usually, the smaller ηOER means the better OER catalytic activity. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural, electronic and magnetic properties of TM-WSSe In view of the asymmetrical characteristic of S and Se atomic layers in Janus WSSe ML, a single TM atom embedded in Janus WSSe ML (TM-WSSe) involves two cases: the lower S surface and the upper Se surface. Fig. 1 (a) and (b) exhibit the optimized configurations of single TM (Fe, Co and Ni) atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S and Se vacancies, respectively. It indicates the formation of three TM-W bonds between each embedded single TM and adjacent three W atoms, without obvious structural distortion compared to the pristine Janus WSSe ML. In order to evaluate whether the embedded single TM (Fe, Co and Ni) atoms can be bonded strongly at the S and Se vacancies, the binding energies ( E b ) are calculated from the following equation: (3) E b = E T M − W S S e − E W S S e − v a c a n c y − E T M where E T M − W S S e , E W S S e − v a c a n c y and E T M stand for the total energies of TM-embedded WSSe, Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy and the isolated TM atom, respectively. Fig. 2 presents the corresponding binding energies of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy, i.e., −4.07 / −4.04, −4.75 / −4.58 and −4.96 / −4.78 eV for S/Se vacancy. The decreasing order (−4.07 / −4.04 > −4.75 / −4.58 > −4.96 / −4.78 eV) of the binding energy suggests the increasing order (Fe-WSSe < Co-WSSe < Ni-WSSe) of binding strength for single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. To further understand the increasing order (Fe-WSSe < Co-WSSe < Ni-WSSe) of binding strength, the d-band centers of the embedded single Fe, Co and Ni atoms in Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy are calculated and shown in Fig. 3 . From the d-band center energy level, the increasing order (−1.14 / −1.17 < −0.86 / −1.03 < −0.43 / −0.58 eV) implies the increasing order (Fe-WSSe < Co-WSSe < Ni-WSSe) of binding strength between the embedded single Fe, Co, Ni atoms and Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy, consistent with the conclusion of binding energy. Notably, all these binding energies are significantly larger than −0.50 eV in magnitude and could be assessed intuitively as chemical binding [72]. To further verify the characteristic of chemical binding, the charge density difference (CDD) and charge transfer of single TM (Fe, Co and Ni) atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy are calculated and depicted in Fig. S1. On one hand, it is obvious that the charge accumulation occurs between the TM and the adjacent three W atoms, reflecting the formation of three TM-W chemical bonds for each embedding TM atom. On the other hand, Bader charge analysis [73] reveals that single Fe and Co atoms serving as the electron donators transfer 0.20 / 0.22 and 0.02 / 0.03 e, respectively, to the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. Whereas single Ni atom acting as the electron acceptor gains 0.06 / 0.07 e from the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. This further confirms the chemical binding between the embedded single TM (Fe, Co, Ni) atoms and the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. Therefore, the single Fe, Co and Ni atoms can suitably embed in the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy, which also provides favorable evidence for the practical feasibility of the Janus WSSe ML modified with a single TM atom. To better reveal the essential mechanism of the single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy, the density of states (DOS) and magnetic characteristics of TM-WSSe systems are further analyzed here. Fig. 4 (a) and (b) plot the spin-polarized DOS diagrams of the single TM atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S and Se vacancies, respectively. A significant orbital hybridization between the TM 3d and the W 5d orbitals occurs in the region of −8 to 4 eV, indicating again that the single Fe, Co and Ni atoms can favorably embed in the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. Furthermore, the magnetic properties of TM-WSSe systems can also be preliminarily evaluated by the symmetry of the upper and lower channels of the corresponding spin-polarized DOS diagrams. For single TM atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S vacancy (Fig. 4(a)), the asymmetrical distribution of Fe- and Co-embedded systems exhibits the magnetic states, while the symmetrical distribution of Ni-embedded system reveals the non-magnetic state. Meanwhile, the total magnetic moments of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S vacancy are computed as 2, 1 and 0 μB, respectively. This point is also held for single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with Se vacancy (Fig. 4(b)). In view of the inherent non-magnetic characteristic of pristine Janus WSSe ML, embedding of single TM (e.g., Fe and Co) atoms could be regarded as an effective method to regulate its magnetic properties. 3.2 Stability of TM-WSSe Considering that the stability of a given catalyst is a prerequisite for its efficient applications, it is quite critical to examine the stability of TM-WSSe systems. In this respect, the thermodynamic stability of the TM-WSSe systems is checked by employing the ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations. A Nosé thermostat [74] within the canonical ensemble is utilized and 1 fs simulation time step is set. After lasting for 10 ps at 300 K (room temperature), the simulation results are obtained and displayed in Fig. 5 , which indicates the slight fluctuations of the potential energies of TM-WSSe systems around their respective averages. The geometrical configurations of TM-WSSe systems also show few structural distortions and basically remain their initial structures. Therefore, the high thermodynamic stability of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy at room temperature is confirmed. Furthermore, the potential clustering behaviors of single TM (Fe, Co and Ni) atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy also need to be examined. Based on the previous similar studies, two possible diffusion paths are considered: (i) the single TM atom diffusing from the embedded S/Se vacancy site to its neighboring optimal binding site [75] and (ii) the single TM atom diffusing from the embedded S/Se vacancy site to the next nearest S/Se vacancy site [76]. For the first path, the optimal binding site of single TM (Fe, Co and Ni) atoms on the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy needs to be determined. There are respective three typical binding sites (hollow site of hexagonal ring and top sites of S/Se and W atoms) on the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. The geometrical optimizations are performed for all the sites, and the most favorable W-top site (top site of W atom) is determined. Thus, the diffusion of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms from the embedded S/Se vacancy site to its neighboring optimal W-top site is analyzed here, and the corresponding results (energy barriers and diffusion paths) are presented in Fig. 6 (a) and (b). It is evident that the diffusion path is an endothermic process and needs to overcome the energy barriers of 2.37 / 2.78, 2.20 / 2.96 and 2.11 / 2.72 eV for the embedded single Fe, Co and Ni atoms on the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. Obviously, such high energy barriers are well above the critical barrier of 0.91 eV [77] for surface reaction at room temperature, suggesting that the diffusion behaviors of the embedded single Fe, Co and Ni atoms from the S/Se vacancy site to its neighboring optimal W-top site are energetically unfavorable. For the second path, the energy barriers and diffusion paths of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms diffusing from the embedded S/Se vacancy site to its next nearest S/Se vacancy site are displayed in Fig. 6(c) and (d). Although the diffusion barriers of 0.52 / 0.69, 0.43 / 0.62 and 0.70 / 0.75 eV are relatively small, it is worth noting that the single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy exhibit the fairly negative binding energies (−4.07 / −4.04, −4.75 / −4.58 and −4.96 / −4.78 eV). This means that the embedded Fe, Co and Ni atoms could be actually very difficult to escape from the strong Fe-, Co- and Ni-W chemical bonds, which may lead to the absence of the subsequent diffusion process. Therefore, the single Fe, Co and Ni atoms would stably embed Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy, and the potential clustering behaviors could be ignored. According to the above analysis, the high stability of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy can be summarized as the following points. First of all, since (i) the considerably negative binding energies (−4.07 / −4.04, −4.75 / −4.58 and −4.96 / −4.78 eV) and absence of further diffusion process, (ii) CDD maps and Bader charge analysis with significantly transferred charge, (iii) spin-polarized DOS diagrams with obviously hybridized TM-3d and W-5d orbitals and (iv) AIMD results with high thermodynamic stability, single Fe, Co and Ni atoms show strong chemical bonding in the Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. Next, single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy (with binding energies of −4.07 / −4.04, −4.75 / −4.58 and −4.96 / −4.78 eV) are expected to exhibit comparable stability with (or even higher stability than) the experimentally well-established electrocatalyst of single Fe atom anchored MoS2 ML (with the binding energy of −2.68 eV) [78]. It is also a favorable evidence for the high stability of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy. Finally, in practical synthesis or applications, the mechanical properties of the Fe-, Co- and Ni-WSSe systems can be further enhanced by using suitable proppants or binders to achieve higher stability. 3.3 Catalytic performance of OER on TM-WSSe After confirming the high stability of TM-WSSe systems, their OER catalytic performance is further investigated in this section. It is well known that ORR is the reverse process of OER and involves two possible reaction pathways in the acidic environment, i.e., 2e- pathway (* + O2 + H+ + e- → *OOH and *OOH + H+ + e- → *H2O2) and 4e- pathway (* + O2 + H+ + e- → *OOH, *OOH + H+ + e- → *O + H2O, *O + H+ + e- → *OH and *OH + H+ + e- → * + H2O), where * denotes the active site on the surface of a given electrocatalyst. In other words, the ORR starts from the hydrogenation of O2 molecule to form *OOH intermediate, then the *OOH intermediate is reduced to either *H2O2 following a 2e- pathway or *O + H2O along a 4e- pathway. As far as the proposed TM-WSSe electrocatalysts are concerned, the selectivity for 2e- or 4e- pathway can be evaluated as follows. For single Fe and Co atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy, it is found that *H2O2 is unstable and would transform into *O + H2O after structural optimization. For single Ni atom embedded Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy, the Gibbs free energy profiles of ORR with two possible reaction pathways are exhibited in Fig. S2. Obviously, the formation of *H2O2 from *OOH intermediate is downhill in the free energy profile by 0.31 / 0.23 eV. Comparatively, the formation of *O + H2O exhibits more favorable downhill in the free energy profile by 1.29 / 1.32 eV. Therefore, the ORR on the TM-WSSe (TM = Fe, Co and Ni) is expected more energetically favorable along the 4e- pathway than the 2e- pathway, suggesting that the TM-WSSe electrocatalysts have excellent selectivity for 4e- pathway in the ORR process. Since OER is the inverse reaction of ORR, it would also take a 4e- pathway and the elementary steps can be expressed as the following equations: (4) * + H 2 O → * O H + H + + e − (5) * O H → * O + H + + e − (6) * O + H 2 O → * O O H + H + + e − (7) * O O H → * + O 2 + H + + e − For the TM-WSSe electrocatalysts, the scheme of OER with 4e- pathway is presented in Fig. 7 , which can be described as follows. First of all, a H2O molecule on the surfaces of TM-WSSe electrocatalysts is dissociated into *OH and H+. Subsequently, the *OH intermediate is further broken into *O and H+. Next, the remaining *O intermediate interacts with another H2O to generate *OOH and H+. Finally, the OH chemical bond of the *OOH intermediate is broken and O2 is produced. As O2 molecule escapes from the surfaces of TM-WSSe electrocatalysts, the configurations of the TM-WSSe electrocatalysts restore their original states and participate in the following cyclic reactions. To quantitatively illustrate the OER catalytic activity of the TM-WSSe electrocatalysts, the corresponding Gibbs free energy profiles are analyzed here. For the single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S vacancy, all the ΔG of OER with 4e- pathway are computed and depicted in Fig. 8 . Meanwhile, the free energy diagram of OER on the pristine Janus WSSe ML (S side) is also displayed together for comparison. To present the energy barrier of each elementary step in the 4e- pathway more intuitively, the correction (1.23 V) for equilibrium potential is adopted in the corresponding free energy profiles. From the highest uphill step (largest energy barrier) in Fig. 8, the rate-determining step (RDS) can be clearly identified, i.e., *O → *OOH (3.00 eV), *OOH → O2 (2.45 eV), *OOH → O2 (1.93 eV) and *OH → *O (1.76 eV) for the pristine Janus WSSe ML (S side), single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S vacancy, respectively. Substituting the ΔG of the RDSs into Eq. (2), the overpotentials (ηOER) are calculated as 1.77 V (= 3.00 eV/e - 1.23 V), 1.22 V (= 2.45 eV/e - 1.23 V), 0.70 V (= 1.93 eV/e - 1.23 V) and 0.53 V (= 1.76 eV/e - 1.23 V), respectively. Similarly, the ηOER for the pristine Janus WSSe ML (Se side), single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with Se vacancy (see Fig. 9 ) are calculated as 1.33, 1.14, 0.82 and 0.53 V, respectively. Obviously, the pristine Janus WSSe ML, Fe- and Co-WSSe with larger ηOER imply their poor OER catalytic activity, and only Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site) with relatively smaller ηOER (= 0.53 V) may show high OER catalytic activity. In particular, compared to the widely approved noble metal OER electrocatalyst IrO2 (ηOER = 0.56 V [79]), Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site, ηOER = 0.53 V) exhibits even slightly smaller overpotential, indicating the potential outstanding OER catalytic activity and promising applications in water splitting as the non-noble metal cost-effective electrocatalysts. 3.4 OER catalytic activity of Ni-WSSe with solvation effect From the above analysis, Ni-WSSe stands out from the pristine Janus WSSe ML and TM-WSSe systems due to its superior OER catalytic performance. Notably, under the condition of solvation effect, the prominent catalytic activity of OER on the Ni-WSSe electrocatalyst needs to be further verified, since the OER process usually takes place in solution. To this end, a solvent dielectric constant of 78.4 within the implicit solvation model is adopted to involve the salvation effect, as implemented in the VASPsol [80]. Fig. S3(a) and (b) present the free energy profiles of OER on the single Ni atom embedded Janus WSSe ML with S and Se vacancies under the solvation effect, respectively. As far as the Ni-WSSe (embedded S vacancy site, see Fig. S3(a)) is concerned, the RDS maintains the elementary step of *OH → *O, while the ηOER is slightly reduced from 0.53 to 0.51 V (= 1.74 eV/e - 1.23 V). As regards another case of the Ni-WSSe (embedded Se vacancy site, see Fig. S3(b)), the RDS still remains the elementary step of *OH → *O, while the ηOER is slightly increased from 0.53 to 0.55 V (= 1.78 eV/e - 1.23 V). Obviously, under the solvation effect, the RDS of OER on the Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site) remains the same, with only a tiny modification of ηOER (decrease/increase by 0.02 V). Therefore, the excellent OER catalytic activity of the Ni-WSSe electrocatalyst with the solvation effect could be further confirmed. 3.5 Mechanism of high OER activity for Ni-WSSe The mechanism of the outstanding OER catalytic activity for Ni-WSSe electrocatalyst needs to be analyzed and summarized so as to provide a meaningful reference for the design of more cost-effective electrocatalysts. Firstly, the adsorption strength of oxygenated species on a given electrocatalyst affects strongly the OER catalytic activity [81]. The classical Sabatier principle suggests the binding strength between a superior catalyst and the corresponding intermediate species should be neither too weak nor too strong [82]. Thus, the adsorption energies of the relevant oxygenated species are analyzed here. The adsorption energies ( E a d s ) of the oxygenated species (*OH, *O, *OOH, O2) on the pristine Janus WSSe ML and Fe-, Co- and Ni-WSSe systems are calculated as follows: (8) E a d s = E A B − E A − E B where E A B , E A and E B refer to the total energies of the substrates adsorbed with the oxygenated species, the substrates (pristine Janus WSSe ML, Fe-, Co- and Ni-WSSe) and the isolated oxygenated species, respectively. The adsorption energy curves of the oxygenated species on the pristine Janus WSSe ML (S/Se side) and Fe-, Co- and Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site) are depicted in Fig. 10 . It can be found that the oxygenated species (*OH, *O, *OOH, O2) exhibit the moderate adsorption on the Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site) but too weak or too strong adsorption on the pristine Janus WSSe ML (S/Se side) or Fe- and Co-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site). Obviously, Ni-WSSe with excellent OER catalytic performance and the pristine Janus WSSe ML, Fe- and Co-WSSe with poor OER catalytic activity conform to the above Sabatier principle. Interestingly, the descending trend (pristine Janus WSSe ML > Ni-WSSe > Co-WSSe > Fe-WSSe) of adsorption energy for the oxygenated species (*OH, *O, *OOH, O2) is consistent with that (pristine WSSe (filled) > Ni (3d8) > Co (3d7) > Fe (3d6)) of occupancy for the TM 3d orbitals. This indicates that the adsorption strength of the oxygenated species (*OH, *O, *OOH, O2) may heavily depend on the 3d orbital occupancy of the active atoms, and Ni-WSSe with superior OER catalytic activity may result mainly from the moderate occupancy of Ni (3d8) active atom. Secondly, an electronegativity difference in the Janus WSSe ML is induced from the unique asymmetric nature of the Janus structure, which would produce a built-in electric field across the asymmetric plane direction. As compared to the conventional WSe2 and WS2 MLs with zero potential difference, the Janus WSSe ML has a lopsided electrostatic potential difference as high as 0.73 eV [55]. Such an intrinsic electric field could inhibit the carrier recombination and accelerate the carrier migration in the Janus WSSe ML, thereby facilitating the OER catalytic activity of Ni-WSSe. Thirdly, since the electrical conductivity of a given electrocatalyst affects strongly the speed of charge transfer and hence the catalytic activity of the electrocatalyst. The electrical conductivity characteristics of Ni-WSSe would be important for the further understanding of the mechanism of its prominent OER catalytic activity. To this end, the electronic band structures of Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site) and pristine Janus WSSe ML (for comparison) are calculated and displayed in Fig. S4. Compared with the pristine Janus WSSe ML, both the conduction and valence bands of Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site) shift slightly to the lower energy regions and generate a few impurity bands, which reduces the band gap from 1.76 to 1.32/1.25 eV. The relatively smaller band gap of Ni-WSSe could be more favorable for charge transfer and have higher electrical conductivity, thereby prompting its catalytic activity. On the whole, the excellent OER catalytic activity of Ni-WSSe is largely attributed to the synergistic effect of the host asymmetric Janus structure and the Ni atom embedding. 4 Conclusions Present work performs systematic investigations on the configurational, electronic, magnetic properties and stability as well as OER catalytic performance of single TM (Fe, Co and Ni) atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S or Se vacancy by utilizing comprehensive DFT calculations. Especially Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site) as a cost-effective OER electrocatalyst is screened out and elucidated. Firstly, the significant chemical bonding of single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded Janus WSSe ML with S or Se vacancy is revealed from the fairly negative binding energies, CDD maps and Bader charge analysis with obviously transferred charge and DOS diagrams with significantly hybridized orbitals. The magnetic states (Fe- and Co-WSSe) and non-magnetic state (Ni-WSSe) are found, and the high stability is confirmed for the TM-WSSe systems. Secondly, Ni-WSSe (embedded S/Se vacancy site) stands out from the pristine Janus WSSe ML and TM-WSSe systems in view of its relatively smaller OER overpotential (ηOER = 0.53 V), even superior to the widely acknowledged noble metal IrO2 electrocatalyst (ηOER = 0.56 V [79]). This may suggest that it could act as a cost-effective OER electrocatalyst with potential promising applications in water splitting. Thirdly, the mechanism of the high OER activity of Ni-WSSe largely benefits from the synergistic effect of the host asymmetric Janus structure and the Ni atom embedding, especially the built-in electric field of the Janus WSSe ML, moderate 3d orbital occupancy of Ni (3d8) atom and good electrical conductivity of the system. In summary, these findings suggest a promising approach and an alternative material for designing the cost-effective OER electrocatalysts, which would inspire and encourage more novel strategies to develop durable, inexpensive and highly efficient OER catalysts for water splitting. coredata.dc:description: Designing cost-effective oxygen evolution reaction (OER) electrocatalysts is of great significance for achieving the renewable energy conversion of complete water splitting. Herein, in the light of the first-principles methods, a series of new OER electrocatalysts (Fe-, Co- and Ni-WSSe) are designed with single Fe, Co and Ni atoms embedded in Janus WSSe monolayer (ML) with S or Se vacancy. It indicates that the single Fe, Co and Ni atoms can stably embed Janus WSSe ML with S/Se vacancy and prominently modify the structural, electronic and magnetic properties of the systems. From the calculated Gibbs free energies, Ni-WSSe presents the prominent OER catalytic activity among the pristine Janus WSSe ML and Fe-, Co- and Ni-WSSe systems due to its minimum overpotential of 0.53 V. The high OER catalytic activity of Ni-WSSe stems mainly from the synergistic effect of the Ni atom and the Janus WSSe ML. Present findings suggest that embedding appropriate single transition-metal (TM) atoms is an effective strategy to boost the catalytic activity of Janus WSSe ML for OER, which would facilitate the development of the cost-effective OER electrocatalysts for clean energy conversion.
coredata.dc:title: Single Ni atom embedded Janus WSSe monolayer as a cost-effective electrocatalyst for oxygen evolution reaction
